title: Bronx Apartment Building Fire Leaves 19 Dead, Many More Injured
summary: Nine children were killed in the blaze; Mayor Eric Adams calls it one of the city's worst fires in modern times. At least 19 people, including nine children, were killed in a fire in a Bronx apartment building on Sunday, New York City fire officials said, in one of the city's deadliest blazes in recent years.

title: U.S. Offers Russia Dialogue, Eyes Sanctions if Ukraine Is Invaded
summary: Resume Subscription. WASHINGTON-As the Biden administration and U.S. allies begin contentious talks with Moscow this week, Western officials are eyeing significant financial punishments and targeted technology sanctions if Russia sends troops across the Ukrainian border, while likely avoiding the broadest energy and bank sanctions, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Omicron Makes Biden's Vaccine Mandates Obsolete
summary: There is no evidence so far that vaccines are reducing infections from the fast-spreading variant.. Federal courts considering the Biden administration's vaccination mandates-including the Supreme Court at Friday's oral argument-have focused on administrative-law issues. The decrees raise constitutional issues as well. But there's a simpler reason the justices should stay these mandates: the rise of the Omicron variant.

title: Meatpackers Are Biden's Latest Inflation Scapegoat
summary: He cries 'gouging' as they face higher costs for labor, fuel and feed.. President Biden has found a scapegoat for rising inflation: the meat industry. Mr. Biden claimed last week that meatpackers-who handle the processing, packaging and distribution of meat raised by farmers and ranchers-are price-gouging, driving a surge in consumer prices for beef, chicken and pork. As they say in cowboy country, Mr. Biden's claim is all hat and no cattle. Unable or unwilling to acknowledge the problems actually driving inflation, Mr. Biden is proposing solutions based on the same failed policies that got us into this inflationary mess in the first place.

title: Paranoia Is a Rational Response to a World Gone Mad
summary: When society is unhinged, you'd be crazy not to think the killers and carjackers are coming for you.. Paranoia, in our time at least, is the better part of valor. Our time is a time of rampant crime: muggings, carjackings, smash-and-grab store lootings, and random murder. I have not been directly affected by any of this marauding, but hearing about it on television and radio news, receiving online flashes about it on my cellphone and stories from friends, I find myself affected by it, as I suspect most people are.

title: China's New Friends in Central America
summary: Salvadoran President Bukele is courting Beijing and playing footsie with thugs.. Impoverished, underdeveloped El Salvador signed a one-year, $1.2 million contract in March with the Washington law firm Arnold & Porter. The K Street lobbyists were supposed to provide to the country "strategic advice and outreach in support of relations with the United States and multilateral institutions." Former State Department official Tom Shannon is one of the registered foreign agents on the account.

title: 'Dear John' Review: Ballistic Missives
summary: The breakup letter from a woman at home to her man in uniform overseas has long been considered to hold a special destructive power.. 'If the Army had wanted you to have a wife, it would have issued you one." It's an oft-repeated quip within the armed forces. As Susan Carruthers demonstrates in "Dear John: Love and Loyalty in Wartime America," it takes a very sturdy relationship to survive the institutional culture of the military.

title: Notable & Quotable: A CNN Epiphany on Covid
summary: 'We need to recognize that getting Covid isn't a moral failing!'. From a Jan. 4 Twitter thread by CNN's Chris Cillizza:

title: The Native American Victims of McGirt
summary: 'There is no protection for me-or anyone like me,' one woman says.. Crystal Jensen had finished a shower one morning in 2019 when she noticed movement out of the corner of her eye. "I didn't have any clothes on," Ms. Jensen says. "And there was a phone up to the window." Her male neighbor, Tobie Munroe, was eventually charged with a felony peeping Tom offense.

title: No Climate Warriors in Frozen Foxholes
summary: Forty-one Democrats urge federal regulators to lower heating prices.. The climate warriors of the Democratic Party aren't lacking for chutzpah, give them that. The latest example is a letter from 41 Members of Congress to federal regulators, fretting about "the effect that anticipated increases in heating and energy costs will have on our constituents this winter." You don't say?

title: Answering Schumer on the Filibuster
summary: Democrats should have taken our advice not to break the 60-vote rule for judicial nominees in 2013.. Chuck Schumer responds nearby to our recent editorial on his plans to ditch the Senate's legislative filibuster, and we're happy to give the Majority Leader his say. But since the Senator challenges us to explain our position on the 60-vote rule, allow us to make the distinctions he slides over.

title: Bill Gardner, Election Federalist, Retires
summary: The New Hampshire Democrat is a cogent critic of H.R.1.. What a run: New Hampshire Secretary of State Bill Gardner, who first took office in 1976, said last week he will soon step down amid his 23rd two-year term. "The two previous secretaries of state died in office," Mr. Gardner told the press with a laugh on Monday. He's now 73.

title: Trump Ally and Skeptic Fill Out Republicans' 2022 Senate Card
summary: Ron Johnson seeks another term in competitive Wisconsin, while John Thune runs again in solid-red South Dakota. Republicans firmed up their Senate lineup to try to win back control of the 50-50 chamber this fall after both Sens. Ron Johnson of Wisconsin and John Thune of South Dakota said they would run for re-election.

title: Covid-19 School Closures Reignite Political Jockeying Ahead of Midterms
summary: Republicans see Biden's education record as providing an opening with voters; Democrats say GOP opposed relief funding for schools last year. WASHINGTON-Republicans are testing out new lines of attack related to the new year's school shutdowns, with party officials seeing Democrats' record on Covid-19 education policy giving them an opening to build their war chests and sway voters in the midterms.

title: Economy Week Ahead: the Fed, Inflation, Consumers
summary: The U.S. consumer-price index, set for release Wednesday, is forecast to top 7% for the first time since 1982. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's confirmation hearing and the latest readings on inflation highlight this week's economic calendar.

title: Russia's Putin Seizes on Crises to Assert Control Over Former Soviet Republics
summary: In tightening grip over neighbors, president seeks to signal that his country is a superpower to be both feared and respected. MOSCOW-The flood of Russian troops into Kazakhstan to help shore up the embattled government sends a clear signal to both the West and other former Soviet republics: Russian President Vladimir Putin will brook no threat to what he views as Russia's inviolable sphere of influence.

title: Taliban Detain Prominent Critic, Intensifying Crackdown on Dissent
summary: Resume Subscription. KABUL-The Taliban have arrested a Kabul university professor who gained national fame for berating a senior official on live television, a sign of the intensifying crackdown on critics of Afghanistan's new regime.

title: U.S. Covid-19 Seven-Day Case Average Tops 700,000
summary: Omicron variant has driven infection levels across the country. The seven-day average for newly reported cases in the U.S. topped 700,000 for the first time, data from Johns Hopkins University show, as the highly infectious Omicron variant spreads throughout the country.

title: What Covid-19 Vaccine Did You Get? You Probably Don't Know Its Name.
summary: Government rules and trademark restrictions limit drugmakers to odd, sometimes unpronounceable names for new prescription medicines. Hundreds of millions of people have gotten the Pfizer Inc.-BioNTech SE and Moderna Inc. Covid-19 vaccine shots. But how many know that the Pfizer vaccine is called Comirnaty? And Moderna's? Spikevax.

title: Russia Readies Planes to Pour More Troops Into Kazakhstan
summary: Moscow says it has prepared more than 75 aircraft for deployment of forces to help Kazakh leadership reassert control. Russia sent fresh reinforcements into Kazakhstan on Sunday, deploying troops to help authorities reassert control in the country's biggest cities following days of sometimes violent protests against its leadership.

title: Is Climate Change in Your Problem Top 10?
summary: 'Limitarianism' may prove to be as deadly as other 20th-century 'isms.'. At a recent dinner, I sat between two men talking past each other. "Mr. Redd" was complaining about our borders and how President Biden's policies have led to the arrest of nearly two million illegal immigrants. "Mr. Bleu" jumped in, "First of all, they're unauthorized migrants. Second, I can't believe you're worried about that. It's not even on my top 10 list." Not one to let a good brawl whimper out unnecessarily, I asked sheepishly, "What's No. 1?" "Climate change," he replied. I couldn't resist. "Really, over failed schools? The homeless? Opioids? Structural unemployment? China?" I asked. "Yup, follow the science," he said. Ugh. He probably thought the dim-witted eco-allegory "Don't Look Up" on Netflix was a documentary.

title: Is the Crisis in Kazakhstan the Rebirth of the Soviet Union?
summary: The West needs to be firm as Putin seeks to expand Moscow's control over neighboring states.. Some commentators saw Russia's deployment of "peacekeeping forces" to Kazakhstan last week as a setback for Vladimir Putin. It showed his weakness, they said. His troop deployments near Ukraine's border were failing, and new popular uprisings could topple autocrats in other former Soviet republics, complicating the Russian president's strategic calculations.

title: Sen. Chuck Schumer Responds on the Filibuster
summary: 'The Republican Party has radicalized against democracy.'. Your editorial criticizing Senate Democrats' efforts to protect Americans' right to vote empowers those who sought on Jan. 6, 2021, to overturn the results of a free and fair election ("Schumer's Filibuster Stunt," Review & Outlook, Jan. 4).

title: The Problem With President Biden's Experience
summary: What do all those years add up to for a career politician?. Regarding William McGurn's column "Sen. Biden's Shrinking Presidency" (Main Street, Dec. 28): I was reminded of an old joke at a bank I once worked for, that our management training program consisted of having the new hire "sit with Jones; he has 30 years of experience." The problem was that Jones didn't have 30 years of experience, but one year of experience 30 times. The same can be said of President Biden and virtually all career politicians.

title: Safe Travels and the 5G Service Launch
summary: Regulators do well to protect pilots and passengers from interference.. Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg and Federal Aviation Administrator Stephen Dickson are rightly defending U.S. leadership in aviation safety-and protecting passengers and shippers-by insisting that telecom companies ensure safety before launching new 5G service that could damage pilots' ability to navigate airliners ("Buttigieg's FAA and 5G Mid-Air Collision," Review & Outlook, Jan. 4).

title: There's More We Can Do to Protect Our Elders
summary: The shift from being caretaker to being in need of care can result in dangerous living conditions.. Regarding "Elder Abuse Is Spreading, Stoked by the Pandemic" (Page One, Dec. 29): I'd like to go further to address abuse perpetrated by mentally ill, drug-addicted or intellectually disabled adults who have been cared for at home their entire lives by their now-senior parents. The pandemic has highlighted the need for comprehensive supportive housing and programming for adults who suffer from mental illness or are otherwise intellectually disabled.

title: Antitrust Is Good for Main Street Businesses
summary: Unless the Robinson-Patman Act is enforced, dominant firms will continue their anticompetitive behavior.. Regarding Noah Joshua Phillips and Joshua D. Wright's op-ed "As Inflation Rises, Antitrust 'Reformers' Target Lower Prices" (Dec. 21): During the darkest days of the pandemic, we rediscovered the important role of Main Street businesses in our communities. Yet when they were needed more than ever, these businesses faced even greater discrimination: higher wholesale prices than competitors and less access to critical goods such as paper products, cleaning supplies and grocery staples. Consumers in rural areas and inner cities bear the brunt of this discrimination. Without enforcement of antitrust laws like the Robinson-Patman Act, dominant firms will continue to engage in anticompetitive behavior.

title: Who Must Be Held Accountable for Jan. 6?
summary: Democrats are not primarily interested in assigning responsibility to everyone who attended.. In "Republicans' Jan. 6 Responsibility" (op-ed, Jan. 6), Karl Rove misses the point: Democrats are not primarily interested in assigning responsibility to everyone who attended the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection. We are far more interested in identifying those who promoted the violence, all the way up to former President Trump.

title: 'Antidemocratic?' That's the Point!
summary: Our republic was founded to withstand the momentary passions of mobs.. "Run, Ms. Ocasio-Cortez, Run," writes the editorial board (Dec. 22) in response to Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's outrage that the Senate is "fundamentally undemocratic." She has also made similar remarks about the Electoral College.

title: Beijing Watches Civil Unrest in Kazakhstan With Wary Eye
summary: Security risks flare anew on China's western frontier, testing closer Sino-Russian ties. TAIPEI-China has much to lose should violence in Kazakhstan grind on or dissolve into civil war. For now, though, Beijing is largely sitting on the sidelines as Moscow, an ideological ally with which it shares many goals in Central Asia, handles the trickier task of suppressing dissent in their oil-rich neighbor.

title: PC Slowdown Sets a New Battleground for Chip Makers
summary: AMD needs to keep taking market share, while Intel can't afford to lose it. After a spectacular run, personal computer sales are expected to cool significantly this year. Ironically, that makes the market an even more important battleground for Intel and Advanced Micro Devices .

title: The Metaverse's Effects on Mental Health: Trivial or Troubling?
summary: Silicon Valley wants to create an immersive virtual world. Is that good or bad news for our well-being?. Author

title: The Best Fitness Apps for Working Out at Home
summary: Pick a fitness platform that has exercises for your fitness level, a variety of workout types and warm-ups to prevent injury. I'm a card-carrying member of Club Living Room. Don't get me wrong: I used to hit the gym at least three times a week. But when I started working-and working out-from home, I became a convert. Mostly because of fitness apps.

title: Europe's Workers See Living Costs Rise, but Pay Isn't Keeping Pace
summary: A weaker recovery has left more slack in Europe's jobs market, while furlough programs have prevented a scramble for workers. Europe's unemployment rate has fallen below its pre-pandemic level, but a surge in wages this year doesn't seem likely even though higher inflation has weakened workers' spending power, according to economists and officials.

title: Here's Why Alabama-Georgia Might Be Fun
summary: The national title game is a rematch of a one-sided SEC game barely a month ago, but this one could go to 11. Georgia plays You Know Who in the College Football National Championship Big Kerfuffle Monday night in Indianapolis, and let's get into it, because even though You Know Who is in this game more or less every year, and Georgia already played and lost to them a month ago, this SEC rematch for everything could get interesting.

title: Europe's Omicron Battle Plan: Hassle the Unvaccinated
summary: Arm-twisting contrasts with U.S. approach; health experts say it would be more effective to make vaccination mandatory. Rarely has a European leader spelled out the continent's Covid-19 strategy as bluntly as French President Emmanuel Macron, who said last week: "The unvaccinated, I really want to piss them off."

title: Why I'm Seeking a Third Senate Term
summary: I'd like to retire, but I think the country is in too much peril.. I decided to run for the U.S. Senate in 2010 because growing entitlements and out-of-control federal spending had exploded our national debt to $14 trillion. We were on an unsustainable path that was mortgaging our children's future.

title: Banks Are Making It Easier to Get Credit Cards
summary: Lenders shunned borrowers with less-than-perfect credit at the start of the pandemic. Now they are embracing them.. Lenders are again welcoming borrowers with less-than-pristine credit, a vote of confidence in the health of the U.S. economy and Americans' finances.

title: Bond Selloff Rattles Markets
summary: A slide in bond prices has pushed the 10-year Treasury yield to 1.769%, its highest since early 2020. A year-opening bond rout has pushed longer-term interest rates to new pandemic-era highs, sending shock waves across financial markets.

title: Omicron Comes to China, Prompting Mass Testing and Quarantines
summary: At least two confirmed cases of new variant reported in port city of Tianjin, weeks ahead of the Winter Olympics in neighboring Beijing. HONG KONG-Chinese health authorities confirmed the country's first cases of domestic transmission of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus in the northern coastal city of Tianjin on Sunday, ordering up testing of millions of residents weeks before neighboring Beijing is set to host the Winter Olympics.

title: Americans' Finances Got Stronger in the Pandemic
summary: Resume Subscription. The Covid-19 pandemic threatened to ruin Americans' finances. For many, the opposite happened.

title: In the Race for Batteries, One Scientist Has Seen It All
summary: Susan Babinec believes cutting-edge science will put the U.S. in the lead again on crucial technology. Much of the technology behind the batteries that power electric vehicles and smartphones came from the U.S. Most batteries are made by Asian companies using materials produced in China.

title: Detroit Makes Its Move in Electric-Vehicle Race
summary: GM, Ford and Chrysler-owner Stellantis look to close gap versus startups. The electric-vehicle race is tightening, with both Ford Motor Co. and General Motors Co. highlighting new electric pickups, and car companies getting ready to release a barrage of new battery-powered models this year and next.

title: Sidney Poitier, Who Blazed a Path for Black Actors, Dies
summary: Actor's cool demeanor and graceful on-screen intensity challenged racial stereotypes in a way that white movie audiences accepted. LOS ANGELES-Sidney Poitier, a trailblazing movie star in the racially charged 1950s and 1960s who became the first Black actor to command top billing in Hollywood films and win an Oscar for a leading role, has died. He was 94 years old.

title: Stock Funds Rose 22.5% in 2021
summary: For a third straight year, stock-fund investors pocketed big gains, but bond funds continued to get more investor cash. Stocks aren't quite immune to the virus, but they continue to overcome it.

title: How the Social-Media Ban Paid Off for Trump, Platforms
summary: One year after being kicked off Twitter, Facebook, Instagram and YouTube, the former president is raking in campaign cash and planning his own social-media company. For an entire year, Donald Trump has been banned from mainstream social-media outlets. For the tech companies and the former president, there have been benefits.

title: Iran Port Key to Alleged Weapons Smuggling to Yemen, U.N. Report Says
summary: Thousands of weapons seized by the U.S. along supply routes for Yemen's Houthis likely originated from Jask in Iran's southeast, according to a draft report. Thousands of rocket launchers, machine guns, sniper rifles and other weapons seized in the Arabian Sea by the U.S. Navy in recent months likely originated from a single port in Iran, according to a confidential United Nations report that provides some of the most detailed evidence that Tehran is exporting arms to Yemen and elsewhere.

title: Earnings Reports This Week Will Help Investors Prep Their 2022 Playbooks
summary: Higher interest rates could make investors less willing to pay rich valuations for stocks. That means corporate profits will be critical to keeping the market climbing.. Earnings season kicks off this week, the next test for a stock market rattled by the prospect of quicker interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve.

title: Supply-Chain Issues Leave New Homes Without Garage Doors and Gutters
summary: Home builders blame bottlenecks for huge backlog of uncompleted homes. Supply-chain backlogs are roiling the new home market, upending efforts to accelerate construction, limiting home-buyer choices, and causing some new owners to move into unfinished homes.

title: Suspect in Assassination of Haitian President Is Detained
summary: Haitian police allege the former DEA informant was in charge of distributing weapons to assailants who killed President Jovenel Moïse. Security forces in the Dominican Republic arrested a former Drug Enforcement Administration informant and convicted drug trafficker who is a key suspect in the assassination of Haitian President Jovenel Moïse, senior Dominican and Haitian officials said Saturday.
